You can't read about things in

The spot where the entry should be is blank, as though the text
were magically excised or transported to some other location.

Entharion the Wise united many warring tribes to form the kingdom of
Quendor. He ruled from Largoneth Castle, near the ancient cities of
Galepath and Mareilon. Our current calendar dates from the first year
of his reign.

Duncanthrax was King of Quendor from 659 GUE through 688 GUE. Known
as the "Bellicose King", he extended Quendor's domain, even conquering
lands across the Great Sea (thus forming what his great-great-grandson,
Dimwit Flathead, named the Great Underground Empire). Duncanthrax was
quite eccentric, and his castle, Egreth, was reputed to be located
in the most dangerous and deadly territory in the known lands.

Lord Dimwit Flathead the Excessive, a descendant of King Duncanthrax, ruled
the Great Underground Empire from 770 GUE until 789 GUE. His accomplishments,
achieved by overtaxing the kingdom, include Flood Control Dam #3 and the
Royal Museum. Extremely vain, he renamed the Great Sea the Flathead Ocean,
and preferred to spend his time in the strange lands that lay across it.

The Wizard of Frobozz was once a member of the influential Accardi
chapter of the Enchanter's Guild. He was exiled by Dimwit Flathead after
accidentally turning Flathead's castle into a mountain of fudge.

Flood Control Dam #3, a great engineering feat, is the source of the
Frigid River.

The article describes the exhibits of the Royal Museum, which included
the crown jewels and a sandstone & marble maze.
Largoneth was the castle of Entharion the Wise.
A short article calls it an ancient city of Quendor.
The entry says "See GREAT UNDERGROUND EMPIRE."

Formerly known as Quendor, the Great Underground Empire reached its height
under King Duncanthrax, began declining under the excessive rule of Dimwit
Flathead, and finally fell in 883 GUE. The area is now called the Land of
Frobozz, after its largest province.
The entry says "See FLATHEAD OCEAN."

The tiniest of articles mentions that Accardi-By-The-Sea is a village
in the Land of Frobozz.
Miznia is a province in the southlands, mostly jungle.

The Frigid River, the mightiest in the Great Underground Empire, runs
from Flood Control Dam #3 to Aragain Falls.

According to this article, Aragain Falls is the most breathtaking
and awesome waterfall in the known lands. It lies at the end of the
Frigid River, and was a favorite honeymoon spot during the 8th and
9th centuries.

Amathradonis was a terrible giant who terrorized Accardi-By-The-Sea for
many centuries. He was finally vanquished by Belboz the Necromancer in
952 GUE.

Nymphs are tiny, magical beings. They are known for their exuberance, fondness
for practical jokes, and willingness to perform small tasks. The leading
temporary nymph services agency is the venerable firm Nymph-O-Mania.

Zork is a classic folk myth about a treasure-hunting adventurer who
became a master of magic. It has been translated into novels, theatricals,
giant wall murals ... almost every imaginable medium.

The encyclopedia describes it as one of the southlands, known for its
fine artisans, and a popular vacation spot.

Antharia an island in the Flathead Ocean, is very prosperous thanks
to its rich marble quarries.
A leading manufacturer of magic scrolls and potions.

The Kovalli Desert lies beyond the mountains that formed the western
boundary of ancient Quendor. It is an uncrossable wasteland, believed
to stretch to the edge of the world.
Lonely Mountain is a towering peak to the west of Largoneth Castle.

A long article tells that Krill was a powerful warlock who plotted to
overthrow the Circle of Enchanters and enslave this corner of the kingdom.
He almost achieved his goal, but was vanquished by a young Enchanter.

The article points out that the Servants Guild is not the most respected
of trade guilds.

It is a corrupt and simplified form of Double Fannucci, popular in taverns,
and frequently played for stakes.

A complex, thinking man's version of Gabber Tumper, and probably the most
popular game in the world.

The capital and biggest city in Frobozz, and the center of the spell
scroll and infotater industries. The port of Borphee is the busiest on
the Flathead Ocean.

The Messengers Guild is among the oldest guilds, and its members are
incredibly dedicated. Their motto is "Not even really bad precipitation
or very early nightfall will prevent us from completing our route."

Temporal travel technology, though in existence for many centuries,
is still considered to be experimental by the magic industry. Several
government agencies are currently looking into its potential long-term
effects.

The Enchanter's Guild can date its roots to the reign of Entharion, over
900 years ago. Chapters are usually located in small villages, since the
bustle of city life interferes with an Enchanter's work ("Excuse me, I
locked my keys in my house. Could you please rezrov my door?"). The most
influential chapter is Accardi Chapter, home of the Circle of Enchanters.

Gnomes are a race of short, furry people known for their greed and business
acumen. They are often employed as toll and fare collectors, bank tellers,
ticket sellers, and presidents of small software firms.

Trolls are a race of ferocious, semi-intelligent creatures. They are often
employed as security guards and bouncers.
The leading supplier of designer spell books.
The head of one chapter of the Enchanters Guild.
A village in the northlands.

According to this article, there are two meanings for Sorcerer. In general,
it refers to a powerful magic-user. More specifically, the term is used
by the Enchanters Guild to denote a senior member of the Circle.
A famous chasm near Accardi-By-The-Sea.
The most prestigious engineering school in the land.

Wasn't that fun?
You'd better settle down before thinking about settling down.

You settle down to sleep, but you really aren't tired, so you
thrash around for a while and then give up.

You drift off to sleep and dream of the distant Kovalli Desert. Waves of
heat from the sand make breathing hard, and the bright sunlight burns
against your eyelids. Suddenly you awake -- the Guild Hall is on fire!
Through the thick smoke, you see Belboz standing before you. But no, this
could not be Belboz, his face an unrecognizable mask of hatred, his
outstretched arms dripping with blood.|
|
He who is not Belboz speaks, in a voice filled with malevolence. "So, you
are the young Enchanter that Belboz thinks so highly of. That senile wizard
thought you would be the one to rescue him from my clutches. I wonder why I
bothered to come at all -- an insect like you poses no threat! Still..." He
gestures and your surroundings change.
Just as you doze off, a wall of water smashes over you!

The vilstu potion wears off as you sleep, and you awaken clawing
frantically at your chest.
Before you fall asleep you pass out from the bad air.
You awake in the middle of the night to find a hellhound gnawing on you.
Your eyes are barely closed before the snake reaches you.
You awake to find snakes and beetles crawling all over you.
Unfortunately, you roll over in the middle of the night. Kaboom!!
Locusts pick your bones clean while you sleep.
You are rudely awakened by the collapse of the rotting drawbridge.

During the night the river bank collapses beneath you, throwing you
into the turbulent waters.

You have a nightmare about a ferocious dorn beast. When it begins gnawing
on you, you realize that it isn't a dream at all.
Amazing how difficult it is to sleep while swimming (and vice versa).
An unknown amount of time later you awake and look around.
You're not all that tired, but the bed is very comfortable.

Hard to believe that you could fall asleep during such an exciting
ride, but you are pretty tired.

Ah, sleep! It's been a long day and rest will do you good. You spread
your cloak on the floor and drift off, renewing your powers and
refreshing your mind. Time passes as you snore blissfully.
You sleep uneventfully, awake refreshed, and rise to your feet.

You materialize in a royal tomb somewhere. Before being devoured by rats,
you notice a well-decayed corpse nearby.

You appear in a strange room. Framed diplomas and wand racks adorn the
walls, and a stuffed owl is perched above a trophy case. An incredibly
old man with a long white beard spots you. "Fertilize!" he cries,
pointing a slightly bent wand at you. You turn into a pile of bat guano,
a fitting end for a trespasser.
You join Krill in oblivion.

You appear in the woods behind the Guild Hall. The servants (who should
be doing their daily chores) are lazing about, drinking ale and betting
on games of Gabber Tumper. To prevent you from reporting their goofing off,
they cut your throat. You just can't get good help these days.

You appear on the lawn of a large estate. A domesticated wolf, foaming
saliva, is chasing the messenger across the lawn. With graceful agility, the
messenger jumps aside, and the wolf sinks its rabid teeth into you instead.

You materialize in the middle of a powerful thaumaturgical experiment. A
Guildmaster stands nearby, but before he can react you have turned into
a large and rather ugly mushroom.

|    ****  You have died  ****||

Your guardian angel, draped in white, appears floating in the nothingness
before you. "Gotten in a bit of a scrape, eh?" he asks, writing frantically
in a notebook. "I'd love to chat, but we're so busy this month."

The angel looks pained. "I hate resurrections in these stupid glass mazes!
I can never tell one room from the next." A moment later, you appear in
the maze. Unfortunately, this is one of the floor-less rooms. This time,
your demise is permanent.

A moment later you find yourself at the bottom of a river, between
a whirpool, some sharp rocks, and a school of river sharks. This time,
your death is terminal.

A look of consternation crosses the angel's face. "According to the
records, you're to be resurrected in your local Guild Hall. But that's
quite far, and I've had a rough day. How about Egreth Castle instead,
hmmm?" Being disembodied, you find it difficult to object, and a moment
later you are among the...
The angel twitches his nose, and the nothingness is replaced by...

Unfortunately, you are still long overdue for a meal and immediately
drop dead again.

Talking to yourself is said to be a sign of impending mental collapse.
Yes?

As you wake up, Frobar sticks his head in the door and invites you
shopping. When you return late that evening, you find the Guild Hall
sacked, and many fellow Enchanters slaughtered. Servants of evil, teeth
smeared with blood, fall upon you as well. A menacing voice echoes about
the room. "Pathetic Enchanters ... Who can save you now?"|
|
Some days it just doesn't pay to wake up.

Belboz, your friend and mentor, is the head of the Circle of Enchanters.

as kingdomwide Secretary of the Guild.

You last saw Belboz a few days ago. You can't begin to

Egreth was the castle of King Duncanthrax.

Helistar is an old and powerful member of the Circle. Although a
skilled and experienced magic-user, she is humorless to the point of
being grim. Despite this personality flaw, Helistar is the most likely
candidate to become the next Guildmaster of the Circle.

Helistar has gone on her annual two-week vacation. She usually goes
to the southlands, Gurth and Mithicus.

Frobar is the most loyal and hard-working member of the Guild. However,
he is somewhat dull and lacks imagination. It is doubtful that he would
ever succeed Belboz as head of the Circle.
Perhaps he's gone into town to perform some errands.

You appear on a road in a far-off province called Cambridge. As you begin
choking on the polluted air, a mugger stabs you in the back with a knife.
A moment later, a wild-eyed motorist plows over you.

Possibly the largest entry in the volume, detailing the facts and the
myths about the man known as the Bearded Oracle of Yonkers.

There's a long write-up in the mythology section. The evil force called
Jeearr once spread pestilence and terror across many lands. Only the
combined magic of many kings and wizards stopped him, even as he was
preparing his final assault. He was imprisoned in the void beyond our
world, his jailors warning future generations that his exile might not
be permanent.

This is the spell book given to you by Belboz after your original book
was lost during your battle with Krill.

There are several spells written in the book, with marginal
notes about their effects and how to cast them.

Thanks to its magic properties, the spell book is always open to the
right place at the right time, but it is also always closed. This innovation
eliminates tedious leafing and hunting for spells in tight situations. Many
wizardly lives have been saved by this advance in magical technology.

Though it is dark, the magic writing of your spells casts enough light
that you can read them.

The river flows quickly by below you.

A wall of water rushes down the river bed as the river returns with

A sturdy toll gate blocks the highway.
Only the gnome can do that.

The gate flies open, waking the gnome, who leaps up and slams it closed
again. "Hey! This is a toll gate! Nobody gets through here without paying
the one zorkmid toll. Not nobody, not no how."

The gate flies open, but the gnome immediately slams it shut again.
"Trying to gate crash, huh? We have an answer for scofflaws like you.
Hey, Tholl!" A troll lumbers out of the toll booth. "This is Tholl
the Toll Troll. Tholl, remove this cheat." Tholl approaches and
slices you neatly in half with his axe.

The gate extends to the roof of the tunnel, and there are pointed
nasties all over it.

As you enter, you stumble over a sleeping troll. With stunning reflexes,
he grabs a battle axe and minces you.
The booth is on the other side of the toll gate.
It's dark inside the toll booth.

A fat old gnome with a long white beard is sleeping soundly just outside
the toll booth. His loud snores echo around the caverns.
A chubby gnome stands behind the toll gate, grinning broadly.

"You'll have to pay the toll first," explains the gnome cheerfully,
"and the toll is one zorkmid."
"Conversing with customers is disallowed by union rules."
The gnome snores loudly.
He's awake!

The gnome opens one eye and looks at you. "You again! Just go through.
Let me sleep." He begins snoring again.

"You again! You've interrupted my nap for the last time! THOLL!!" A
huge troll lumbers out of the toll booth and tears you into itsy-bitsy
pieces.

The gnome stirs a bit and opens one eye, which wanders around until it
notices you. He jumps to his feet. "One zorkmid, please," he yells
with a smile.
The gnome is asleep, remember?

You carefully search the sleeping gnome, and take the zorkmid coin you
find in his pocket!

The gnome pockets the coin and opens the gate. Before you can take a
step the gnome falls asleep again.

The thoughts of the sleeping gnome are focused on certain activities
involving female gnomes. Embarrassed, you withdraw.

The thoughts of the gnome seem evenly divided between getting money from
you and getting back to sleep.

The gnome refuses, saying "That coin is giving off light, and is

"Well?" asks the gnome, tapping impatiently. "You've interrupted
my nap. Are you going to pay the toll, or not?"

You are at the boarding platform of a fast-moving flume, flowing

north.

In order to prevent damage to public life and property, flumes are
protected against this sort of prank.

Flumes are artifical water channels, usually with boat rides. The
boat is typically a hollowed-out log. The largest flume of this kind
is in Bozbarland.
Huh?
Bad time to leave the log boat. The flume is fast and rough.

As you enter the log boat, it lurches away from the platform and is
carried swiftly away by the current of the flume.

The flume is wide here, and straight as an arrow.
The ride is quite relaxing.

You enter a stretch of sharp, winding curves! Spray dashes your face as you
are tossed about the log boat!

The twists and turns are left behind as you approach the
mouth of a dark tunnel.

The flume winds through a tunnel whose walls are black as coal.
You pass an opening which provides a brief glimpse of troglodytes
digging and hauling coal.

It is pitch black. The roar of the flume's current echoes about the tunnel.
A spot of light is visible ahead.

The log boat leaves the tunnel and passes through a series of rapids, shooting
straight toward jagged rocks and then veering away at the last moment!

Magically, the flume flows uphill here! The current slows as the boat
climbs and climbs...

You reach the crest of the flume's final drop. You can see swirling
white water below!

The log boat plunges down into the swirling waters at the base of
the slope! Huge splashes of water spray off in every direction, but
amazingly you stay dry!

The boat floats serenely around a final turn and pulls up to the boarding
platform.

You are at the boarding platform of a huge roller coaster, sprawling
above and around you in every direction.
south.
Huh?

Dumb idea. Your body ricochets off several wooden supports as it
plummets to the ground.
As you enter the car, it rolls away from the platform in a gentle curve.

The car, propelled by some unseen force, rolls up a huge incline. The
crest grows tantalizingly closer.

You reach the crest, the highest point of the roller coaster! The park
is laid out beneath you like a map; the lights of the midway, the
booths of the arcade, the sparkling blue ribbon of water that must be
the flume. In the distance is a wide crater. The sounds and smells of
the park seem distant, and time feels suspended for a moment.

The breath is swept from your lungs as the car begins diving,
seemingly straight downward. You rise from the seat as the ground
rushes closer! At the last moment, the car swings upward, and your
stomach settles in your ankles.

The car zips through a series of wild turns and sharp drops. Wooden
roller coaster supports whiz past, inches from your head!

This section of track is shaped like a corkscrew, and as the car hurtles
forward it turns upside down almost every second. It is impossible to tell
up from down, as the ground seems to spin around you.

The car shoots into a rapid climb, which gets progressively slower and
steeper. Your heart beats wildly as the track begins to swing back above you,
and you realize that you are entering a giant loop!

As you reach the highest point of the loop, you hang completely upside-down
for a brief moment. The blood rushes to your head as the ground suspended
"above" you like a canopy. Then, you hurtle down the far side of the loop
with breakneck speed!
The roller coaster speeds out of the loop and into a tunnel

, which seems to run through the middle of a haunted house! Wispy ghosts and
ghoulish skeletons brush past you
. You shiver as horrible slimy things brush across your face

The car zooms out into daylight, and glides to a stop at the

"C'mon, pal!" cries the hawker from the game booth. "Try your luck!"
He holds the ball out toward you.
The hawker yells after you, "Hey buddy, come back with that ball!"
The hawker pushes you away.
"No time to gab, kid.
C'mon and give it a try. One hit wins!
The hawker is thinking about finding a good stogie, whatever that is.

You appear in an amusement park game booth. The point of the game is to
pierce balloons with darts. Speaking of points, you are suddenly pierced
by 37 flying darts.

A tremendous pitch sends a bunny spinning. "What an arm, kid, what an
arm!" cries the hawker. He hands you a glittering scroll from the shelf
of prizes. "Here's your prize, now scram."

This game is harder
than it looks. The hawker, leering, retrieves the ball.

The bunnies hop away and the startled hawker scrambles after them. He
returns a moment later, holding the again inanimate bunnies, and gives
you a nasty glare.

You enter just as a group of casino nymphs finish cleaning up the last
of the zorkmid coins.

Ping! Ping! Ping!|
A zorkmid coin drops out of the machine and lands at your feet.
You see nothing but reflected light in all directions.

According to the article, Duncanthrax built the Glass Maze on a whim,
to amuse his friends and torture his enemies. A labyrinth of 27 cubicles, it
was full of devilish pitfalls and was located near his castle, Egreth.
Too narrow even for bats.
Where did you get the bizarre notion that you might fit up a chimney?

The statue transforms into a living figure, probably a King if the royal
attire is any clue. The King seems angry, and quickly settles his wrathful
gaze on you. He bellows "Guards! Throw this trespasser into the glass
maze! Guards! ... GUARDS!!!" When the guards fail to respond, the King
becomes livid, his voice rises to an incoherent squeak, and flecks of foam
spit from the corners of his mouth. Finally, eyes bulging with rage, he
storms out of the room.
The King moved too quickly to follow.

You are inside a huge cubical maze, shimmering with light from an unseen
source above.

It is impossible to tell if the walls and ceilings around you are
glass surfaces or openings.

Since you are standing on something, the floor must be solid, but it is
virtually invisible and you feel as though you were walking on air.

fly
walk
right into an almost invisible wall of glass -- a stunning blow!

Unfortunately, this section of the glass maze has no floor.
Bug #14

"Caw! Caw!" A giant bird of prey with a fondness for gnusto-receptive
paper swoops down and flies off with your spell book.

The structure is about two feet on each side, and extends up from the
ground about three feet. Except for a large quantity of soot around the
opening, it looks a lot like a small, rectangular well.
The opening is dark and you can only see a few feet into it.
The
disappears into the shaft.
The shaft extends beyond your reach.
The corpse comes to life just long enough to fry you.

With a loud roar, a dreadfully huge dorn beast emerges from the
shadows at the base of the cliff and gallops toward you.
From outside the maze, you hear the bellowing of a ferocious dorn beast!

The dorn beast rushes after you. Its ear-splitting bellowing
resounds throughout the glass maze.

Suddenly, the dorn-beast realizes that it is galloping through midair,
and gives a surprisingly high-pitched squeal. It claws frantically at thin
air, trying desperately to invent dorn beast flight. You happily notice that
dorn beasts do not so much fly as plummet.

The dorn beast fries your brain with its hypnotic gaze and begins
secreting digestive juices.
Such menial tasks are best left to troglodytes.
That passage is now completely blocked by a cave-in.
Part of the ceiling collapses onto you.

There is a rumbling noise behind you as the ceiling of the tunnel collapses,
blocking your retreat! The air smells strongly of coal gas.
Good thing you took that vilstu potion
You won't survive long in this atmosphere
A few lumps of coal spill from the coal chute.
Finally, the shortage of oxygen gets to you.
You are about to pass out from the bad air.
It's full of coal.
You find nothing of interest.
You'll have to drop the beam before doing that.

disappears into the chute.

You here a commotion from the room to the west.
Someone is standing near the coal bin.
Your older self then looks at you, almost expectantly.
From the next room you glimpse someone gasping for air.
Someone is standing near the coal bin.
Your look-alike dives into the lower chute and slides out of view.

Someone in the coal bin room dives into the lower chute.
Your older self dives into the lower chute.

The shaft is too wide.

It disappears into the shaft. A moment later comes a distant thud.

You'd have to take the rope out of the chute first.
A rope hangs from the beam, into the chute.
A rope is tied to the beam.
A troglodyte trundles in and dumps a load of coal into the chute.
The troglodyte trundles off into the coal mine.
The troglodyte ignores you.
You didn't notice which passage it took.
The troglodyte is worried about filling his coal quotas.

Semi-intelligent subterranean beasts frequently used to dig and haul
coal.
You climb carefully down the rope, which is slippery with coal dust,
but because of your fatigue you lose your grip.
but because of your load you are unable to maintain your grip.
and soon reach a small opening off the chute. You clamber inside...
Wheee!!!
You land beside an enormous bin of coal.
As you
float
whiz

down the chute, you notice a flash of orange light spilling
from an opening onto the chute.
Wheeee!!!

Mounted securely to the wall is a kerosene lamp, filling the room
with a serene orange glow.
A small compartment at its base is open.

The lamp has a glass bowl where the flame burns. Below is a small metal
door, perhaps a compartment for storing extra wicks or kerosene.
It's mounted securely to the wall.
You can't spare the breath to blow out the lamp.
The chute is too narrow to fly up.
The chute is too steep and slippery.
You're already at the
top
bottom
of the chute.
As you slide down the chute, some of your possessions suddenly vanish!
You fly out of the chute and land just at the edge of some water...
Suddenly, without the slightest fanfare, you cease to exist!
You are
floating above
standing on

the western shore of the mighty Flathead Ocean. According to legends
you read at the University, the eastern shore of this ocean is a strange
land of magical beings and priceless treasures.

You could go north along the shore; the edge of a small cove lies to
the southwest.

The beach to the south is blocked by a tall cliff; a lagoon shore
lies to the northwest.
The ocean lies far below you.
It streches east as far as the eye can see.

The Flathead Ocean, called the Great Sea by the ancients, has a very
unusual feature -- its western shore basks in the sunlight while its
eastern shore lies far underground.
Certain death.
The cliff is too high to fly over.
The cliff is unclimbable.
The water looks calm and hospitable.
The water level seems to drop an inch or two, for a moment.
You are
flying over
swimming on

the surface of a calm lagoon, whose sandy floor is visible below.
A curved beach surrounds this inlet on its western side.
You won't be able to hold your breath much longer.
Better get some fresh air soon!
You run out of air and drown.
The coral is covered by swaying spenseweeds.

The spenseweeds wilt away, revealing a wooden crate labelled with
black lettering.
That's difficult -- they're well rooted in the coral.

on

The can seems empty.
There is a sloshing sound from inside.
The repellent is all gone.
The spray stinks amazingly for a few moments, then drifts away.

The spray smells like a mixture of old socks and burning rubber. If
I were a grue I'd sure stay clear!
That horrible smell is much less pungent now.

A mighty river spills into the ocean here. Looking up the river valley,
you see a tall waterfall. Atop a cliff, high above you, is the rampart
of a fortress. A cave entrance
at the base of the cliff to the west is blocked by writhing green vines
lies to the west
Suddenly you realize that, without really thinking about it, you were
flying
walking

toward the wriggling vines. As you stop, a feeling of annoyance
seems to radiate from the plants.
You can almost feel a wave of pain from the vines as they shrivel away.

Your attack is somewhat quixotic as the vines wrap around and tear
you to pieces.
The vines encircle you and tear you limb from limb.
The grues lurk toward you! Your last sight is a hundred slavering fangs.
Suddenly, you are set upon by countless slavering fangs!

One of the grues gives off a flash of light but, strangely, it doesn't seem
to notice or care.

They stagger about the room, covering their noses and making horrid
gurgling noises.

They seem to be ignoring you, aside from a few suspicious gurgles
in your direction.
Baring tremendous fangs, they form a circle around you...
There are terrifying gurgling noises from the darkness!
A pack of grues fills the room!

The grues, contrary to all conventional wisdom, aren't bothered by your
light in the least. They must be mutated grues, no longer fearing light!
A field of energy leaps forth, reducing you to a pile of smoldering ash.

You notice, on one machine, a tiny plaque which reads:|
|
FROBOZZ MAGIC MUTATED GRUE BREEDER CO.

Hideous parasites descend upon you and tear the flesh from your bones,
gnaw the eyes from your sockets, and feast upon your very brain tissue.
Amazingly, you do not die, and your body regenerates itself as you await
the next attack...

Disembodied forces suck the very thoughts from your mind, savoring
each moment and growing stronger. Every second is an agonizing torment,
as though thousands of raging fires were exploding in your skull,
filling you with a pain greater than you could ever imagine.
Your agony is too great to concentrate on such an action.

As the door opens, hundreds of slime-covered tentacles stream
out and drag you across the threshold...

The door blows open, knocking you to the ground. You are pulled
through the open doorway by an unseen force...

The door creaks slowly open. Within, you see someone lying as though
asleep. You feel yourself drawn into the room...

Your head feels numb for a moment, and your mind feels suddenly open and
unprotected.

As you stab Belboz, an apparition rises from his body. Floating above him
like a cloud of fog, it howls with laughter. A moment later, gaspar begins
to heal the wounds, and the spirit flows back into the body.

You stab the knife time and again into Belboz, who writhes in pain,
eyes bulging outward. Sickened and dizzy, you stagger back.
A wispy translucent shape rises from the
corpse
body

of Belboz. It speaks in a voice so deep that your whole body seems to
hear it. "Foolish Charlatan! I am forced to flee that weak, old body -- I
shall take your own, instead! Already I have sucked all knowledge, all
secrets from that ancient Enchanter. Now begins an epoch of evil transcending
even your worst nightmares; a reign of terror that will last a thousand
thousand years!" The shape blows toward you on a cold wind.

Jeearr surrounds you like a cloud and begins to contract. Suddenly, it
strikes your invisible protection and recoils as if burned. "No!" it
cries. "Such a guileless Enchanter developing a mind shield?" The cloud
is thinner, the voice fainter. "It cannot be! I cannot survive ... without
a host." The demon roils in agony, then thins and dissipates. There is a
final scream of pain, then silence.

Jeearr is vanquished; the kingdom is saved. But you - you are stranded in
a land unknown, and your closest friend, the greatest Enchanter of his
age, lies dead by your own hand. Kneeling by his blood-soaked corpse, you
beg for another chance...

Belboz moans softly, and begins stirring. He sees you and rises, instantly
alert. After posing a few well-chosen questions, he casts a brief but
unfamiliar spell.|
|
An instant later,
your grue suit has vanished and

you are standing in the Chamber of the Circle. The Circle of Enchanters
is assembled. Belboz speaks. "Once again, this young Enchanter has done
a matchless service to the Guild and to the entire kingdom, displaying
resourcefulness and imagination worthy of the greatest of Enchanters. I
grow old, and must soon step down as Head of the Circle. But let it be
known that a successor has been found."

Here ends the second chapter of the Enchanter saga, in which,
by virtue of your skills, you have been appointed as the next
leader of the Circle of Enchanters. The final adventure awaits
you as the Enchanter series concludes.
You hear a distant bellow. "What happened to my morgia plant?"

You feel an overwhelming sense of oppression as the demon seizes control
of your mind and body. The monster reaches into the recesses of your mind,
adding your hard-earned magic powers to its own. As it settles comfortably
into your skull, the demon grants you a vision of the future. You see the
enslaved people of the land toiling to erect great idols to Jeearr. Parents
offer up their own children upon these altars, as the rivers of the land fill
with blood. And YOU embody Jeearr; you are cursed by ten thousand generations
of victims; your face adorns the idols. And worst of all, you remain awake
and aware, a witness to horror, never sleeping, and never, ever to escape.

Suddenly, Belboz's eyes flicker and he leaps to his feet. His face is
unrecognizable, a twisted mask of hatred. "Meddlesome Enchanter! I should
have killed you all before I left! But better late than never..." Lightning
bolts flash toward you from his fingers, but rather than dying, you find
yourself in the...
